conclusion: Analysis of thermal motion during Stirling cycle
Stirling cycle has four processes: A→B isothermal expansion, B→C process to be analyzed, C→D isothermal compression, D→A process to complete the cycle
To determine if thermal motion becomes more intense during B→C, need to determine temperature change
Thermal motion intensity is directly related to temperature
For an ideal gas, temperature is proportional to average kinetic energy of molecules
B→C shows decreasing pressure with decreasing volume in P-V diagram
B→C is neither clearly isothermal, isobaric, nor isochoric
For an ideal gas, PV = nRT where n, R are constants
At point B: Higher pressure, higher volume
At point C: Lower pressure, lower volume
PV product is decreasing from B to C
Since PV is decreasing and T ∝ PV, temperature must be decreasing from B to C
Lower temperature means less thermal motion of molecules
Final answer: No, thermal motion does not become more intense from B to C; it becomes less intense due to temperature decrease
